video.title: Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Oh hello, Ubisoft! I was just talking about one 
of your old games last week and how it&#39;s odd you

didn&#39;t milk the IP until its udders turned into 
crumbling black stalactites like some properties I

could mention. But listen to me go on, what&#39;s new 
with you? Oh, a Prince of Persia game. Speak of

the devil. Or the ifrit or the djinn or whatever&#39;s 
most appropriate for your multicultural team of

various religious faiths and identities you&#39;re 
always banging on about. Oh, he&#39;s lost a crown,

now, has he? That&#39;s what happens when you eat 
too many Werther&#39;s Originals. Prince of Persia:

The Lost Crown is a new side on hack and slasher 
quasi-soulslike Metroidvania and its connections

to previous Prince of Persia canon are tenuous at 
best. In fact, the titular Prince of Persia isn&#39;t

even the character you control. The Prince 
of Persia is a rosy-cheeked smooth-palmed

mummy&#39;s boy whom the protagonist is called 
upon to rescue from Bowser&#39;s castle. Hell,

later on in the plot someone is revealed to 
also be *a* Prince of Persia and they&#39;re not

the fucking protagonist either. Talk about the 
glass ceiling. No, the only thing that connects

Lost Crown&#39;s protagonist to established Princes of 
Persia is that they live in Persia and they&#39;re a

hunky boy with a posh accent who runs around with 
no shirt on. ...alright, consider me on board.

Said protagonist is Sargon, who is a member of 
the Immortals, and isn&#39;t that a weirdly popular

word these days. Not to be confused with the 
Immortals of Aveum or the Immortals that Fenyx

Rising was hanging out with, the Immortals are 
a colourful band of elite warriors charged with

the defense of ancient Persia. There&#39;s a big 
one and a smart one and a leader and one in a

fetish outfit that the others don&#39;t like to talk 
about and as they were introduced in the course

of the tutorial mission my immediate thought 
was &quot;Boy, I&#39;m looking forward to whatever plot

contrivance means we have to have boss fights 
against all these lads. Place your bets people,

is it going to be surprise betrayal 
or mind control? Spoiler warning: yes,

it was one of those. But when they do become boss 
fights, some of them come across like they were

really hankering for an excuse to kick Sargon&#39;s 
teeth in anyway. Seems like he&#39;s failed to endear

himself to his fellows, probably because he&#39;s the 
youngest and prickliest and gets really pissed off

when the others bump into him in the corridor 
and do the &quot;Oh I beg your pardon, Sargon&quot; joke.

Anyway, yeah, the Immortals head off to rescue 
the Prince from a weird interconnected collection

of themed lands where reality&#39;s gone a bit 
skewiff and thus does a Metroidvania game

begin. The standard Metroidvania assessment 
is the Start To Double Jump metric, or STDJ,

how far into the game you have to get before 
you the double jump unlocks, which marks the

point the game designers officially ran out 
of ideas. Prince of Persia: The Roast Clown

has a decently long STDJ, and generally has a very 
solid fast-paced core gameplay, even if it suffers

a bit from the Ghost of Tsushima problem that 
it works best only once you&#39;ve played it long

enough for it to dribble out all the mechanics 
that make it work. You start off with the bog

standard abilities that hack and slash games 
have to have by law now apparently - you hack,

you slash, you dodge, you parry, there&#39;s 
attacks that glow red you have to dodge,

attacks that glow yellow you have to parry 
in accordance with the combat system highway

code - but as you unlock a few of the specials 
and some of the more interesting traversal

abilities you can start turning fights into 
full on anime battles with lots of yelling,

and shooting brightly coloured energy out of 
your fists and teleporting behind each other.

You can do all kinds of crazy acrobatic combos 
in this game. I know, &#39;cos I saw a Tiktok video

of someone doing one. You wouldn&#39;t know 
from watching me play the game, fuck no,

I got by perfectly well by mashing attack 
and pressing block or dodge now and again,

which is poking our little snuffling snout into 
my first major issue with Prince or Persia:

The Tossed Pot - an excess of unnecessary bloat, 
in both the gameplay systems and the environment.

Let&#39;s not forget this is a triple A publisher 
slumming it in double A land, and triple A has

gone way beyond eating all the pies. It&#39;s fucking 
patented eating all the pies so it can bring

legal action against anyone who nibbles on their 
discarded crust, and Ubisoft just couldn&#39;t shake

the ingrained instinct to shove in way too much. 
Into the pies. You can see the stretch marks every

time you have to go to the four corners of the map 
to get bullshit magical Maguffins A, B, C and D so

the actual plot can budge forward an inch, or 
when you get caught by a boss&#39; attack for the

fifth fucking time that locks you into a thirty 
second unskippable cutscene of Sargon getting

his shit pushed in. And that&#39;s just the critical 
path. There are entire areas of the map that only

exist because I assume some of the hundred million 
names in the end credits were trying to look busy.

And I know you think a game being too big is a 
good problem to have that only game critics with

deadlines whine about but it means the various 
optional pickups that are the brick and mortar

of Metroidvania are spread a bit thin. Nothing 
more annoying than doing yourself a mischief

getting through a gauntlet of whirring blade 
traps - which were incidentally the only times

it felt like I was actually playing a Prince of 
Persia game - only for your reward to be a pair

of blue trousers instead of white. Or a handful of 
cash, when there&#39;s nothing left to buy except an

upgrade for that one useless amulet that makes 
your toenails grow 30% faster. But I shouldn&#39;t

grouse too much, this is after all what I keep 
asking big publishers to do - split the blood

money between a bunch of solid lower scoped 
lower budget projects instead of one billion

dollar Assassin&#39;s Creed game every six years 
that nobody fucking wants. And Prince of Persia:

The Jock Strap is a solid game. The story&#39;s not 
mind blowing and the visuals are kinda bland

with that &quot;sorta cel shaded but sorta not&quot; look 
that triple A tends to use when it&#39;s pretending

to not be triple A. But none of that&#39;s the 
focus. The focus is on a perfectly decent core

traversal-combat gameplay loop that&#39;s fast and 
fun to experiment with and satisfying to pull off.

Which is all it needs. Let&#39;s face it, 2D hack and 
slash Metroidvania has basically been perfected as

a formula. One should bloody hope so, the number 
of them there are. It can only be improved in

small ways now, like shaving a tenth of a second 
off your speedrun record. Prince of Persia:

The Boss Baby achieves that by adding the ability 
to take screenshots and paste them to the map,

so you can remember what you need to come back 
to. An idea so great I immediately wondered,

cynic that I am, which obscure indie Metroidvania 
Ubisoft ripped it off from. Although I don&#39;t like

how you&#39;re only allowed a limited number of 
snapshots, and increasing that number is gated

behind pickups thrown in as more grist for the 
optional collectibles mill. &#39;Cos it&#39;s a quality

of life feature, really, it&#39;s like forcing us 
to do a gameplay grind before we can unlock a

volume slider. I wanted to absolutely plaster 
my map in screenshots &#39;til it looked like a

red string conspiracy board. And then when 
I was done with the game I wanted to get my

aunt and uncle around and get revenge for the last 
time they talked me through their holiday snaps.
